KALAMAZOO COUNTY JUVENILE HOME
1424 GULL RD,
KALAMAZOO, MI, 49048-1605
Re: License #: CO390201216
SI #: 2025SIC0000294
Dear Peter Daniel Holt:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Samantha Way at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,
Paul Fatato, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
427 East Alcott St.
Kalamazoo, MI 49001
(269) 251-2471

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Employment policies and procedures; establishment
Title
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10107
Section (1) A facility shall establish and follow written employment policies
Description and procedures that shall assure that staff are emotionally stable
and of suitable health, ability, experience, and education to
perform the duties assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Unknown staff at the facility have also openly bragged about
"aggressive" restraining techniques they have used on unknown
children at the facility. It is unknown if these incidences resulted in
an injury. There is a suspicion that these concerns may still be
ongoing.
Investigation Complainant 1 was interviewed via phone on 1/16/2025.
Complainant 1 reported partnering with the facility twice a week
and was informed of the allegations by Complainant 2.
Complainant 1 also reported the partnering involved Complainant
1 working with different youth (unable to recall names) twice a
week at the facility. Complainant 1 was unable to provide any
details or specific information about the facility but was able to
provide the phone number for more information.
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on 1/16/2025. Staff 1
reported over hearing Staff 18 say Staff 18 “beat Youth AD’s ass
when restraining Youth AD” and “Staff 18 also said Staff 18 will
slam Youth AD on Youth AD’s face again”. He reported doing
nothing with this information.
Administrator 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
1/16/2025. He reported remembering the restraint (April 2024) of
Youth AD by Staff 18 but also reported Youth AD is no longer at
the facility. He reported never hearing about Staff 18 or any other
staff bragging about a restraint and if hearing about any staff
bragging of a restraint he would take disciplinary action with that
staff.
Staff 2, Staff 3, Staff 4, Staff 5, Staff 6, Staff 8, Staff 9, Staff 10,
Staff 11, Staff 12, Staff 13, and Staff 15 were interviewed face-
to-face on 1/16/2025, separately. They all reported never
hearing a staff brag about slamming a youth during a restraint or
3

telling a youth the staff will “beat the youth’s ass”. They also
reported if they heard a staff say something negative towards a
youth they would speak to the staff about the language and inform
a supervisor of the staff’s behavior.
Staff 14 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
1/16/2025. She reported staff might talk about a restraint after the
restraint occurs and would say the staff took the youth to the
ground if the youth needed to go to the ground. She also reported
all staff say this and was unable to identify any specific staff. She
reported hearing one staff (unable to recall who) say they
slammed a youth (unable to identify the youth) to the ground but
did nothing with this information.
Supervisor 7 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
1/16/2025. He denied hearing any staff at any time talk about a
restraint in an inappropriate manner. He also reported if he heard
such talk from a staff, he would speak to the staff and then report
to a supervisor. He reported if staff engage in such talk, they
should receive further training, and all restraints are reviewed on
video recordings to ensure proper techniques are used.
Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, Youth E, Youth F, Youth
G, Youth H, Youth I, Youth J, Youth K, Youth L, Youth M,
Youth N, Youth O, Youth P, Youth Q, Youth R, Youth S, Youth
U, Youth V, Youth W, Youth X, Youth Y, Youth Z, Youth AA,
Youth AB, and Youth AC were interviewed face-to-face at the
facility on 1/16/2025, separately. They all reported never
observing or hearing staff engage in inappropriate talk about
restraints and all also reported feeling safe at the facility.
Youth T was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
1/16/2025. He denied hearing staff talk about restraints in an
inappropriate manner nor talk about restraints in front of the youth.
He also reported staff have cursed at Youth T but was unable to
give any specifics as to when and which staff.
Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, Youth F, Youth J, Youth K, Youth
L, Youth O, Youth Y, and Youth Z were interviewed face-to-
face at the facility on 1/16/2025, separately. They all reported
staff provided constant supervision to the youth.
Attempts were made to contact Youth AD on 1/30/25 and
2/10/25 and messages were left for a call back. However, no
call back was received from Youth AD.
4

Supervisor 1, Supervisor 2, Supervisor 3, and Supervisor 4
were interviewed via phone, separately on 1/22/2025. All
Supervisors denied hearing or being informed of any staff talking
inappropriately about a youth or what the staff would do to the
youth. They also reported the same process if hearing of such a
behavior from a staff. They would pull the staff aside and speak
with the staff before reporting the incident to Administration. They
also reported the facility works to avoid restraints as much as
possible. They reported staff are to debrief about a restraint but in
a manner that allows the staff to examine what they could have
done to avoid the restraint.
Staff 16 was interviewed via phone, on 1/22/2025. He denied
hearing any staff talk about a restraint in an inappropriate manner.
Staff 17 was interviewed via phone, on 1/22/2025. She denied
hearing any staff talk about a restraint in an inappropriate manner.
Staff 18 was interviewed via phone on 1/22/2025. He denied
hearing any staff at any time talk about a restraint in an
inappropriate manner. He also reported if hearing such talk from a
staff, he would speak to the staff and then report to a supervisor.
He also reported the facility tries to avoid restraints as much as
possible.
Supervisor 6 was interviewed via phone on 1/24/2025. He
reported never hearing or being told of a staff bragging about a
restraint. He also reported the process for a restraint involves a
debriefing with the youth and staff involved along with a supervisor
watching the video of the restraint to ensure it was done per
policy. The other aspect of supervisors watching the video is to
learn if other actions rather than a restraint could have taken
place.
Staff 19 was interviewed via phone on 1/24/2025. He reported
never hearing anyone brag about a restraint but also reported
hearing other staff (unable to identify who these staff were)
complain about someone bragging about a restraint. He reported
there are some poor relationships between staff but declined to
give any specific staff names.
Staff 20 was interviewed via phone on 1/27/2025. He denied
ever hearing a staff member brag about a restraint. He also
reported he would inform a supervisor if hearing something like
that.
5

Staff 21 was interviewed via phone on 1/27/2025. She reported
talking with other staff involved in a restraint about the restraint,
but no one was bragging about the restraint. She also reported
that had occurred in the past and being unable to remember who
the staff were that were talking about a restraint.
Staff 22 was interviewed via phone on 1/27/2025. He reported
never hearing staff talk about a restraint of a youth in a negative
manner or in a bragging tone.
Staff 23, Staff 24, Staff 25, Staff 26, Staff 28, Staff 29, Staff 30,
and Staff 31 were interviewed via phone, separately on
1/28/2025. All reported never hearing staff talking in a bragging
tone about a restraint of a youth.
Staff 27 was interviewed via phone on 1/28/2025. He reported
hearing staff talk about restraining youth (but was unable to recall
the manner the staff were speaking about the restraint) and was
unable to recall specific staff. He also reported trying not to pay
attention when hearing other conversations.
Staff 32, Staff 33, and Staff 34 were interviewed via phone,
separately on 1/29/2025. All reported never hearing staff talking
in a bragging tone about a restraint of a youth and if they heard a
staff speak in this way they would inform a supervisor or
administrator.
Supervisor 5 was interviewed via phone on 1/29/2025. He
reported never hearing nor being informed of a staff talking about
restraining a youth in a negative or bragging tone. He also
reported if hearing or being informed of this occurring, he would
speak to the staff and engage a counseling (discipline) action with
the staff.
Staff 35 was interviewed via phone on 1/29/2025. He reported
never hearing staff talk about restraining a youth in a negative or
bragging tone. He also reported hearing staff talk about restraints
but in a positive way of processing the incident in hopes of
learning different options.
Staff 36 was interviewed via phone on 1/30/2025. He reported
never hearing staff talk about restraining youth, but staff will
debrief after each restraint. He also reported that he would speak
to the staff about the inappropriate talk if hearing any.
6

The video of the restraint was reviewed by Administrator 1, but he
reported since the restraint took place approximately 10-months
ago, it was no longer available. The facility does not keep video
for that length of time.
Documents Reviewed:
• Kalamazoo County Juvenile Home Policy 2.18
Professional Boundaries without a date. This document
outlines that these professional boundaries are defined by
the clear demarcation of the employee’s role as a
professional in each employee/resident interaction. Another
aspect documented is serving as an appropriate role
model. It is documented that staff shall not engage in
making negative comments about other residents.
• Incident Report Kalamazoo County Juvenile Home for
Youth AD dated 4/11/24. This document outlines the
restraint of Youth AD on 4/11/24 and lists Staff 36 as being
involved. Staff 18 and Supervisor 7 are documented as
being witnesses to the restraint and Staff 36 is documented
as the author of the report. The incident is documented as
occurring at 8:00 am in the library. Staff 36 documented a
description of the incident which indicates, Staff 36
responded to a “level 1” issue and when arriving in the
library, assisted Staff 18 in restraining Youth AD. Staff 36
held Youth AD’s left arm and Staff 18 held Youth AD’s right
arm. It is documented when Supervisor 7 came on site,
Youth AD walked to the holding unit without incident. It is
documented when Youth AD was asked for a description of
the incident, Youth AD denied the incident.
• Incident Report Kalamazoo County Juvenile Home for
Youth AD dated 4/11/24. This document outlines the
restraint of Youth AD on 4/11/24 and lists Staff 18 as being
involved. There is no staff documented as witnessing the
restraint and Staff 18 is documented as the author of the
report. It is documented that Staff 18 overheard Youth AD
and another youth (unidentified) arguing and Staff 18
stands between the two youth (Youth AD and unidentified
youth). Staff 18 documents getting the unidentified youth
into the classroom but having Youth AD continue to attempt
to get towards the unidentified youth. Staff 18 placed Youth
AD against the wall while trying to deescalate Youth AD.
Because Youth AD continued to struggle, Staff 18
documented taking Youth AD to the ground as Staff 36
entered the room and assisted by grabbing Youth AD’s left
arm. Staff 17 entered the room and assisted with holding
7

Youth AD’s legs. When standing Youth AD up it is
documented that Youth AD is bleeding from the mouth or
nose as they moved Youth AD to the holding unit.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as evidence by interviews with
staff, youth, and written documentation. The few staff who
reported to have heard another staff talk about a restraint in a
negative manner were unable to identify the staff or the specific
details of when and where it occurred. None of the youth reported
hearing staff talk about restraints in a negative manner and the
only youth reporting staff curse at youth was unable to provide
specifics about the cursing.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Heating equipment
Title
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10419
Section
Description (1) Heating equipment shall be capable of maintaining a
temperature of not less than 68 degrees Fahrenheit at a point 4
feet above the floor. An accurate thermometer shall be provided.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation There is concern for the heat not working properly in the juvenile
home. It is unknown how long the heat has not been working but
could have been for the past week. It is unknown when the heat is
going to be fixed. The temperature could be between 60-65
degrees, but that is not certain. Staff in the facility are giving the
children extra blankets in the meantime.
There is no heat in the facility. At this time, it is unknown when the
heat will be back on in the facility. The children were provided with
an extra blanket
Investigation Complainant 3 was interviewed via phone on 1/22/2025. She
reported speaking to Youth X yesterday (1/21/25) and being told
the heat was now working at the facility. She also reported the
facility lied to her because she was told the heat was fixed on
Sunday but told by Supervisor 2 on Sunday the heat was not
fixed. She was unable to recall who informed her the heat was
fixed on Sunday. She reported Supervisor 2 informed her staff had
given 2 extra blankets to all youth.
Complainant 4 was interviewed via phone on 1/22/2025. She
reported receiving a text from Probation Officer 1 yesterday that
8

the heat is now working at the facility. She also reported being told
by Youth V that staff gave all the youth 2-extra blankets when the
heat was not working.
Complainant 5 was interviewed via phone on 1/22/2025. She
reported she heard about the lack of heat through social media.
She also reported hearing from her Complainant 4 that the heat
was fixed. She reported having no further information to add.
Probation Officer 2 was interviewed via phone on 1/22/2025.
She reported having no knowledge of the heating except it was
out for a period of time and she heard about it through social
media. She also reported a memo went out from Probation Officer
1 to the community explaining the situation.
Probation Officer 1 was interviewed via phone on 1/22/2025.
He reported having limited information but that the heating is now
working. He also reported understanding the youth were provided
extra blankets.
Administrator 2 was interviewed via phone on 1/22/2025. He
reported the blower for the furnace did stop working on 1/19/25
but was repaired on 1/20/25. He also reported staff provided an
extra 2-blankets to the youth on the two pods where the blower
was broken. This allowed for these youth to have a total of 4-
blankets plus extra sweatshirts were provided to the youth. Staff
continued to monitor the temperature, and a plan was put into
place if the temperature continued to decrease, these youth would
be moved to another pod that did not have the heating issues. He
provided a detailed outline of the actions taken during this time
frame of Sunday and Monday. See the description of the incident
in the documents reviewed section below.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed via phone on 1/22/2025. He
reported understanding there were issues with the heating, but the
temperature did not reach a dangerous level. He also reported the
heating issues have been repaired.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed via phone on 1/22/2025. She
reported working when the heat issues began and receiving a
phone call from Complainant 3 on Sunday night and reported
Youth X called Complainant 3 and reported the heat loss at the
facility. Supervisor 2 also reported trying to explain to Complainant
3 that Supervisor 1 was informed by the maintenance staff
working on the heat that it was not the furnace but the blower that
was not working. Supervisor 2 reported telling Complainant 3 that
9

the heat was working because the return vent was providing heat.
Supervisor 2 also reported Complainant 3 did not accept what
Supervisor 2 was telling Complainant 3 about the situation with
the heat. Supervisor 2 reported informing Administrator 2 of the
phone call with Complainant 3. She also reported developing a
plan to move the youth to another part of the facility if the area
they were currently in did not begin to warm up. However, after
the return system was fixed the area began to warm up again.
She reported all youth were provided with 2 extra blankets which
gave them each a total of 4-blankets. She also reported each
youth was given a sweatshirt. She reported testing the
temperature throughout her shift with a plan to move the youth if
the temperature dropped too much. She also reported when she
left her shift the rooms were much warmer and almost to a normal
temperature.
Supervisor 4 was interviewed via phone on 1/22/2025. He
reported working the overnight shift the day the heat issues
began. He also reported being informed the blower was the issue
by Supervisor 2 when getting to work. He was informed the
maintenance staff who was working on the issue didn’t have the
blower part to fix the blower but were able to make sure heat was
still going into the area. He reported all the youth were provided
with extra blankets and he provided extra supervision on the
effected pods throughout the night. He also reported having a plan
to move the youth if the heating system had another failure during
the night. He reported when returning to work Monday evening,
the heating was working as normal.
Staff 18 was interviewed via phone on 1/22/2025. He reported
being present on Sunday when the heating issue began. He also
reported this issue only effected Pod C and Pod D and the rest of
the building had heat as normal. He reported the youth on these
pods were given extra blankets and there was a plan to move the
youth to other pods if the temperature dropped to much. He also
reported the heat was still working throughout the incident but was
limited until fully fixed. When returning to work on Monday, the
situation had been fixed.
Staff 21 was interviewed via phone on 1/27/2025. She reported
coming into work at noon on the day of the heating issue. She
also reported the pod was not as warm as normal and the youth
were given 4-blankets. She reported when returning to work the
next day, the heating was working as normal
10

Staff 27 was interviewed via phone on 1/28/2025. He reported
working at the time the problems with the heating began. He also
reported beginning to feel the pod cooling down and not hearing
the blower working. He reported notifying Supervisor 5 who came
down to the pod. He also reported not knowing when the issue
was fixed and didn’t have knowledge of extra blankets being
provided to the youth because he had left work.
Supervisor 5 was interviewed via phone on 1/29/2025. He
reported being in the effected pod around 7:30 am to pass out
medication when he noticed the pod was cooler than normal and
he didn’t hear the blower. He also reported maintenance showed
up at 8:30 am and he informed maintenance about the cold on the
pod. He reported maintenance reported the blower was not
working and the “boss” of maintenance was called. He also
reported about an hour later the “boss” of maintenance came to
the facility and reported the blower motor was “fried”. He reported
being informed by maintenance that maintenance would have to
find a new blower motor. Supervisor 5 passed this information on
to Administrator 2 and a plan was developed to move the youth if
necessary. He also reported more maintenance personal showed
up and were able to get heat flowing back into the pod around
2:00 pm, when the return vent was opened. He reported the
blower was replaced Monday morning (next day) early in the
morning. He also reported the temperature did not get that cold
but if it did, the youth would have been moved. He reported youth
were provided extra sweatshirts and given 4-blankets.
Staff 33 was interviewed via phone on 1/29/2025. He reported
being present when the issues with the heat on pod C and pod D
occurred. He also reported Supervisor 5 kept checking the
temperature and the heat was fixed on Monday. He reported staff
made sure each youth had good socks and sweatshirts to wear.
He also reported youth were given extra blankets and a plan to
move the youth was developed if necessary.
Staff 34 was interviewed via phone on 1/29/2025. She reported
being present when the issue with the heat on pod C and pod D
began. She also reported the heat was fixed as fast as possible
and the youth were provided with sweatshirts and extra blankets.
She reported the plan was to move the youth to another pod if the
temperature dropped to much.
Staff 35 was interviewed via phone on 1/29/2025. He reported
working when the heating issues began on pod C and pod D. He
also reported walking onto the pod and feeling it was colder, so he
11

notified Supervisor 5. He was told to provided extra blankets to the
youth and maintenance was working on fixing the problem. He
reported later in the day the pods were much warmer.
Walk Through:
A walk through was conducted at the facility on 2/6/25 with a focus
on the Pods that were to have lost heat in the allegations. Both
pods were warm and there was no presence of a lack of heat in
either nor the space between the pods. The building overall was
well heated.
Documents Reviewed:
Kalamazoo County Juvenile synopsis of a heating issue on
1/19/2025:
Sunday 1/19/25 Approx. 7:45am:
• Supervisor 5 noticed it was cold on C pod/D pod while
passing morning meds.
• He stated that it was not necessarily cold, but he noticed
that it was colder than down in A pod/B pod where the heat
was fully functional.
• He stated that he could tell that the blower wasn’t running,
it was noticeably quieter on C pod/D pod than A pod/B pod.
Sunday 1/19/25 Approx. 8:30am:
• Supervisor 5 notified Buildings and Grounds (B&G) on-call
worker of the potential problem with the heat.
• B&G worker was in the building conducting his morning
rounds.
• B&G worker confirmed that there was an issue with the
“blowers” on C pod/D pod.
• B&G worker notified his boss to our issue with the heat.
Sunday 1/19/25 Approx. 11:00am:
• Several B&G workers arrived to assist with our issue.
• B&G again confirmed that a “blower” was broken. Heat
was being produced but it was not being fully distributed
into C pod/D pod.
• B&G began working on a solution and locating parts.
Sunday 1/19/25 Approx. 1:00pm:
12

• Supervisor 5 notified Administrator 2 (Dep. Admin) and
Administrator 1 (Admin) after B&G confirmed the heating
issue.
• Supervisor 5 and Supervisor 2 (Supervisor) developed a
plan to move residents into other units where the heat was
fully functioning if necessary.
• Supervisor 5 and Supervisor 2 also developed a plan to
distribute extra blankets to the residents closer to bedtime.
Sunday 1/19/25 Approx. 2:30pm:
• Additional B&G workers arrived to assist with fixing the
“blower.”
• Temporary fix was performed to push warm air into C
pod/D pod.
• B&G ensured us that C pod/D pod would be warm going
forward. B&G was actually concerned that the units might
be too warm until the “blower” was replaced.
• B&G was still in search of replacement unit at this time.
• Supervisor 5 and Supervisor 2 confirmed that the units
were gradually warming up.
Sunday 1/19/25 Approx. 3:00pm:
• Administrator 2 arrived to check on the situation. The pods
were observed at a comfortable temperature.
• B&G again confirmed that they were doing everything in
their power to obtain the replacement unit.
• Supervisors were instructed to keep a close eye on the
temperature of C pod/D pod to ensure that temps continued
to rise.
Sunday Overnight:
• Supervisors continued to monitor the
situation. Temperatures remained comfortable overnight.
• Even with the temperatures returning to normal, extra
blankets were handed out to each resident to ensure that
they were warm enough.
Monday 1/20/25 8:00am:
• B&G arrived first thing in the morning with the replacement
unit.
• Replacement unit was installed by 8:30am, and we were
fully functional shortly after that.
13

• Ninth Circuit Court, Kalamazoo MI dated Tuesday,
January 21, 2025, 5:00 pm. This document outlines the
statement that was released to the County, social media,
and Court website. The memo states that the facility was
not without heat, but a blower unit malfunctioned and
stopped in one isolated area on Saturday. The County’s
Building and Grounds (B&G) did an excellent job repairing
the malfunction within hours. The heating system remains
fully operational, and blankets were handed out to the
youth which is a common practice anytime the temperature
drops.
• Memo from Buildings and Grounds dated 1/22/2025 at
10:56 am. This document outlines the sequence of events
about the heating issue from the B&G team’s perspective.
On Sunday 1/19/25 at approximately 11:00 am it is
documented the B&G maintenance technician was
conducting a routine weekend building check when it was
discovered the lower temperatures in Pods C&D. The on-
call B&G supervisor was notified and to mitigate the
problem, a 40-minutes override on the Air Handler Return
Air Fan to circulate warm air into the affected area. It is
documented the Maintenance Manager and Maintenance
Supervisor arrived on-site and discovered the Variable
Frequency Drive alarm was active and preventing the Air
Handler Supply Fan from operating. It is also documented
Moore Electric was called for assistance and arrived on-site
at 1:30 pm. Moore Electric diagnosed the issue as a failed
Air Handler Supply Fan motor. As a temporary solution, the
Air Handler Return Fan was set to override and the heating
control valve was adjusted to maintain the space
temperature at approximately 73 F. This fix remained until
the following day. On Monday 1/20/25 a replacement Air
Handler Supply Fan motor was sourced and installed. This
is documented as being completed by 9:30 am which
restored full service and normal operations.
• Metasys Trend Export period reviewed December 25,
2024 to January 23, 2025 created on January 23, 2025.
This document outlines the average value (temperature) is
documented as 71.9 and during the time of the blower
failure, the temperature dropped to 66.8 before the return
vent was changed. Once this change occurred, the
temperature reached 74 before completed repairs were
made.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as evidence by interviews with
staff and written documentation. Although there were problems
14

with the heating system at the facility, the facility responded
appropriately and provided for the care of the youth appropriately.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was offered for staff to have portable
temperature gauges so the temperature of a specific area can be
reviewed at any time. This action should also be documented for
future reviews if needed.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Facility and premises maintenance
Title
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10403
Section

Rule Code Resident restraint
Title
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10177
Section (1) The facility shall establish and follow written policy and
Description procedures specifying the use of resident restraint.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
19

Allegation Youth AD suffered an injury during a restraint. Bit his tongue and
was bleeding when going to the ground.
Investigation Staff 18 was interviewed again via phone on 1/30/2025. He
reported remembering the restraint of Youth AD on 4/11/2024. He
also reported trying to keep Youth AD from contacting another
youth (unidentified in report and could not remember). Staff 18
was able to get the unidentified youth into a classroom before
pushing Youth AD to the wall in the room. Staff 18 reported taking
Youth AD to the ground because Youth AD was being violent and
trying to get away from Staff 18 and at the unidentified youth. This
resulted in Staff 18 placing Youth AD on the ground and Staff 18
also reported Youth AD bit Youth AD’s lip as they went to the
ground. Staff 18 reported trying to get Youth AD to calm down
throughout the incident, but Youth AD refused. Staff 18 also
reported the blood observed was from Youth AD biting Youth AD’s
tongue. Staff 18 reported Staff 36 came in and helped hold the left
arm of Youth AD and Staff 17 helped hold the legs of Youth AD.
Staff 18 denied ever bragging about slamming Youth AD to the
ground and reported some of the youth (didn’t remember who)
were spreading this rumor.
Staff 17 was interviewed via phone, on 1/30/2025. She reported
entering and supporting the restraint after Youth AD was on the
ground. She was unable to recall the staff involved but also
reported Youth AD was fighting the restraint and refused to calm
down. Staff 17 reported observing blood on Youth AD’s face but
unsure how the injury occurred.
Staff 36 was interviewed via phone on 1/28/2025. He reported
remembering the restraint of Youth AD in the library area and
described the incident as outlined in the incident report. He also
reported Youth AD was bleeding when Staff 36 arrived and has no
knowledge of what caused the bleeding. He reported Staff 18
used appropriate CPI techniques as much as Staff 36 observed.
Supervisor 7 was interviewed via phone, on 1/30/2025. He
reported remembering the restraint and having reviewed the video
recording of the incident. He also reported Staff 18 stepped
between Youth AD and another youth (unable to recall who) to
stop them both from fighting. He reported not recalling Youth AD
on the ground but did remember Staff 18 having Youth AD against
the wall to stop Youth AD from getting to the unidentified youth.
He also recalled Youth AD informed Supervisor 7 that Youth AD
had bitten Youth AD’s inside lip when he fell to the ground.
Supervisor 7 reported Staff 18 followed the approved techniques
but still had Staff 18 go back through a refresher training of CPI.
20

Supervisor 7 also reported providing ice and pain medication for
Youth AD at the time and a notice was sent to the nurse at that
time. It was reported the nurse was a temporary staff at the time
because the facility was in the process of hiring a full-time staff.
Administrator 1 was interviewed via phone, on 1/30/2025. He
reported remembering the restraint but believes it has been too
long since the incident for the video recording to still exist. He also
reported reviewing the video with Supervisor 7 and finding nothing
inappropriate in the techniques used by Staff 18. He reported Staff
18 was breaking up a fight and trying to keep Youth AD from
continuing the fight. However, Youth AD was fighting with Staff 18
to continue the fight causing Staff 18 to engage in the restraint.
Staff 18 attempted a basket hold causing Staff 18 and Youth AD
to fall to the floor because of the aggressiveness of Youth AD. At
this time Staff 36 came into support followed by Staff 17.
Administrator 1 reported the least amount of force was used by
Staff 18 when falling to the floor.
Attempts were made to contact Youth AD on 1/30/25 and
2/10/25 and messages were left for a call back. However, no
call back was received from Youth AD.
Documents Reviewed:
Incident Report Kalamazoo County Juvenile Home for Youth
AD dated 4/11/24. This document outlines the restraint of Youth
AD on 4/11/24 and lists Staff 36 as being involved. Staff 18 and
Supervisor 7 are documented as being witnesses to the restraint
and Staff 36 is documented as the author of the report. The
incident is documented as occurring at 8:00 am in the library. Staff
36 documented a description of the incident which indicates, Staff
36 responded to a “level 1” issue and when arriving in the library
assisted Staff 18 in restraining Youth AD. Staff 36 held Youth AD’s
left arm and Staff 18 held Youth AD’s right arm. It is documented
when Supervisor 7 came on site, Youth AD walked to the holding
unit without incident. It is documented when Youth AD was asked
for a description of the incident, Youth AD denied the incident.
Incident Report Kalamazoo County Juvenile Home for Youth
AD dated 4/11/24. This document outlines the restraint of Youth
AD on 4/11/24 and lists Staff 18 as being involved. There is no
staff documented as witnessing the restraint and Staff 18 is
documented as the author of the report. It is documented that
Staff 18 overheard Youth AD and another youth (unidentified)
arguing and Staff 18 stands between the two youth (Youth AD and
21

unidentified youth). Staff 18 documents getting the unidentified
youth into the classroom but having Youth AD continue to attempt
to get towards the unidentified youth. Staff 18 placed Youth AD
against the wall while trying to deescalate Youth AD. Because
Youth AD continued to struggle, Staff 18 documented taking
Youth AD to the ground as Staff 36 entered the room and assisted
by grabbing Youth AD’s left arm. Staff 17 entered the room and
assisted with holding Youth AD’s legs. When standing Youth AD
up it is documented that Youth AD is bleeding from the mouth or
nose as they moved Youth AD to the holding unit.
HR record for Staff 18 was reviewed. Staff 18 was hired on
6/26/2023. There is no documentation of discipline in the file and
Staff 18 is current on his required trainings.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as evidence by interviews with
staff and written documentation. Evidence suggests staff
engaged in the restraint as trained and because of Youth AD’s
resisting the restraint and efforts to continue the altercation, Youth
AD and Staff 18 went to the floor resulting in an injury to Youth
AD’s mouth area. Administrator 1 reported reviewing the video
recording of the restraint and finding no inappropriate use of
restraint techniques by Staff 18.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was offered to the facility that video
recording of restraints that are viewed have a documented
assessment of the review by administration staff. This
documentation should be available for future reviews.
Conclusion Violation Not Established

Rule Code Clothing.
Title
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10161
Section
Description Each resident shall have sufficient, clean, properly fitting,
seasonally appropriate clothing.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The facility has a history of not meeting the children's basic needs.
In the later end of 2024, children at the facility did not have access
to socks, underwear, or appropriately sized shoes.
Investigation Complainant 1 was interviewed via phone on 1/16/2025.
Complainant 1 reported partnering with the facility twice a week
and was informed of the allegations. Complainant 1 also reported
the partnering involved Complainant 1 working with different youth
(unable to recall names) twice a week at the facility. Complainant
1 was unable to provide any details or specific information about
the facility but was able to provide the phone number for more
information.
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on 1/16/2025. Staff 1
reported underwear is tied together to make holes for the legs
because the underwear is ripped and torn and the youth needed
to wear underwear. Staff 1 also reported there is a shortage of
socks because youth don’t have socks for everyday use.
Administrator 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
1/16/2025. He reported not remembering being informed of the
facility running low on underwear. He also reported all staff have
the responsibility of throwing out underwear that is damaged or
has holes, along with any clothing that has holes or is damaged.
Staff can ask for more clothing to be purchased at any time and
Administrator 3 will purchase needed clothing. He reported the
staff observing underwear as described in the allegation should
28

have thrown out the underwear and obtain a new pair. He also
reported the facility is purchasing approximately 100 pairs of
socks per month and each youth receives two pairs of pants,
shirts, sweatshirts, socks, and underwear at time of intake. He
reported clothing is washed every night and the staff washing the
clothing will throw away clothing that has holes. He also reported
youth tend to get holes in their socks quickly causing significant
requests for more socks.
Administrator 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
1/16/2025. She reported part of her tasks are to purchase clothing
for the facility to be used by youth. She also reported purchasing
socks once a month and will purchase 9-packs of 12-socks per
pack. She reported ordering underwear when the supply begins to
run low and will order “100’s of pairs at a time and will order shirts
and pants in bulk. She also reported there is no written procedure
for replacing damaged clothing.
Staff 2, Staff 3, Staff 4, Staff 6, Staff 7, Staff 9, Staff 10, Staff
11, Staff 12, and Staff 13 were interviewed face-to-face on
1/16/2025, separately. These staff reported youth have
appropriate clothing and if there are holes in the clothing, it is
thrown away by staff and replaced. They reported the process of
replacing generally involves staff calling a floater to find new
clothing while the primary staff can stay with the youth to
supervise. They also reported youth do not go without clothing
items. All reported shoes are provided and if not having the right
size, youth are given a larger sized until the correct size is found
which generally occurs within a day.
Staff 5 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
1/16/2025. She reported working the overnight shift and will throw
out clothing that is damaged. She also reported the youth get new
clothing to replace damaged clothing that was thrown out.
Supervisor 7 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
1/16/2025. He reported socks and underwear are switched out
daily and youth are given clean underwear and socks daily. He

Analysis The facility is found in compliance as evidence by interviews with
staff, youth, written documentation, and an on-site inspection. No
lack of clothing was observed, and the overwhelming number of
staff and youth all reported no issues with the clothing. Most staff
and youth reported the same process for the disposal of clothing
with holes or other damage as staff are to throw the item away.
Most staff knew of the process for obtaining new clothing items
and evidence suggests the facility will locally purchase clothing
items if there is a shortage of the items. There was only a couple
of staff who believed the socks and underwear were an issue, but
they also reported not knowing the process for replacing clothing
items.

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical Assistance was offered to develop a logistic tracking
system that ensures an accurate accounting of clothing is always
on hand. This will allow the facility to ensure timely purchasing of
clothing items in a timely manner.
Technical Assistance was offered to retrain all staff on the clothing
policy/procedure to ensure all staff are aware of the process.
Technical Assistance was offered to develop a policy/procedure
for the purchasing and providing new clothing and the action to
take to remove damaged clothing.
Conclusion Violation Not Established

Walk through:
A walk through took place and the television in the allegations was
located. The television was inspected, and it was found to be a
“smart television” with several streaming apps already on the
television. Looking at the YouTube app, it was found to have an
account that had not been authorized by the facility administration.
This is the account noted in the allegations. When opening this
account, it was found to have inappropriate music videos of
women dancing in sexual manners. However, another video was
found which matches the allegations of a women only wearing a
see-through leotard while wearing nothing else and cleaning a
room. The television was taken down and the identified staff (Staff
6) whose channel was identified was interviewed.
Documents Reviewed:

Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance as evidence by interviews
with staff, youth and an on-site inspection of the television. Staff 6
admitted to observing his channel on YouTube that contained
sexually inappropriate material which he also admitted to opening
on the television.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical Assistance was offered to develop a policy/procedure
that if staff observe staff engaged in inappropriate behaviors, the
staff observing the inappropriate action is required to report the
action to a supervisor and document the action.
Technical Assistance was offered that the facility removes all

the facility.
Technical Assistance was offered that all televisions being used in
the different Pods be mounted so the camera has a clear picture
of what is being shown on the television.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
